title-part.text: FUNCTIONAL FEATURES OR DETAILS COMMON TO BOTH SMALLARMS AND ORDNANCE, e.g. CANNONS

note.note-paragraph: This subclass covers those features or details which are considered to be of a kind generally applicable to, or to be concerned with intrinsic functions common to, both smallarms and ordnance.
Such features or details are classified in this subclass, even if they are stated to be applied only to smallarms or only to ordnance.
Attention is drawn to the definitions given in Note (2) following the title of class F41.
In this subclass non-limiting references (in the sense of paragraph 39 of the Guide to the IPC) may still be displayed in the scheme.

title-part.text: Missile propulsion characterised by the use of explosive or combustible propellant charges

reference.text: projecting missiles without use of explosive or combustible propellant charge F41B; launching rockets or torpedoes F41F3/00; missile self-propulsion F42B15/00

title-part.text: Hypervelocity missile propulsion using successive means for increasing the propulsive force, e.g. using successively initiated propellant charges arranged along the barrel length
Missile propulsion using the combustion of a liquid,
or gaseous fuel, e.g. hypergolic fuel

Adjusting the range without varying elevation angle or propellant charge data, e.g. by venting a part of the propulsive charge gases, or by adjusting the capacity of the cartridge or combustion chamber

reference.text: adjusting the range by using gas-relieving ports in the barrel F41A21/28

title-part.text: Recoilless guns, i.e. guns having propulsion means producing no recoil
a counter projectile being used to balance recoil
Block action, i.e. the main breech opening movement being transverse to the barrel axis
about a horizontal axis transverse to the barrel axis at the rear of the block
carrying a rotably mounted obturating plug of the screw-thread or the interrupted-thread type
Bolt action, i.e. the main breech opening movement being parallel to the barrel axis
Rigid bolt locks, i.e. having locking elements rigidly mounted on the bolt or bolt handle and on the barrel or breech-housing respectively
the locking elements effecting a rotary movement about the barrel axis, e.g. rotating cylinder bolt locks
Straight-pull operated bolt locks, i.e. the operating hand effecting only a straight movement parallel to the barrel axis
the locking being effected by rotating the operating handle or lever transversely to the barrel axis
the locking elements forming part of the operating handle or lever
semi-automatically or automatically operated, e.g. having a slidable bolt-carrier and a rotatable bolt
having fixed locking elements on the non-rotating bolt and rotating locking elements mounted on the barrel or breech housing, e.g. rotatable rings
Interlocking means, e.g. locking lugs, screw threads
the bolt being rocked about a notional axis transverse to the barrel axis
the bolt additionally effecting a sliding movement transverse to the barrel axis
Semi-rigid bolt locks, i.e. having locking elements movably mounted on the bolt or on the barrel or breech housing
having rocking locking elements, e.g. pivoting levers or vanes
having sliding locking elements, e.g. balls, rollers
Bolt locks of the unlocked type, i.e. being inertia operated
the bolt being provided with an additional slidable mass
Breakdown breech mechanisms, e.g. for shotguns
Breech mechanisms for guns having two or more barrels

reference.text: F41A3/58 takes precedence; for revolving-cannon guns F41F1/10

title-part.text: using combustion gas pressure for adding to the mechanical locking action, or for delaying breech opening movement
Accessories for breech-blocks or breech-block mountings
Bolt stops, i.e. means for limiting bolt opening movement
Anti-rebound arrangements, i.e. preventing rebound of the bolt out of the firing position

reference.text: safeties for locking the breech-block or bolt in a safety position F41A17/42

title-part.text: Mounting thereof in breech-blocks or bolts
Obturating or packing devices for gas leak prevention in breech mechanisms
specially adapted for sealing the gap between the forward end of the cartridge chamber and the rearward end of the barrel, e.g. sealing devices for revolvers or revolver-type guns
Mechanisms or systems operated by propellant charge energy for automatically opening the lock
the barrel being tilted during recoil
the barrel being rotated about its longitudinal axis during recoil
having an accelerator lever acting on the breech-block or bolt during the opening movement
mounted in a gun having a fixed barrel
Barrel stops, i.e. devices for holding the recoiling barrel in a predetermined position, e.g. the recoil position
having a barrel moving forwardly after the firing of a shot
using a gas piston arranged concentrically around the barrel
having two or more gas pistons
by direct action of gas pressure on bolt or locking elements
Arrangements or systems for bleeding the gas from the barrel
Gas- or recoil-operated, e.g. selection of gas- or recoil-operated systems
Energy accumulator systems, i.e. systems for opening the breech-block by energy accumulated during barrel or gas piston recoil
Auxiliary mechanisms for bringing the breech-block or bolt or the barrel to the starting position before automatic firing
Machine gun rechargers, e.g. manually operated
Drives for externally-powered guns, i.e. drives for moving the breech-block or bolt by an external force during automatic firing
using a rotating cylindrical drum having a camming groove

title-part.text: Guiding means for the extracting of cartridges

using cyclically moving conveyors, i.e. conveyors having ammunition pusher or carrier elements which are emptied or disengaged from the ammunition during the return stroke

title-part.text: using a movable magazine or clip as feeding element

note.note-paragraph: Feeding elements or concepts of general interest, not specially adapted for feeding multibarrel guns, are classified in groups F41A9/01 or F41A9/29.

title-part.text: Feeding two or more kinds of ammunition to the same gun

CPC-specific-text.text: Feeding propellant charges and projectiles as separate units

note.note-paragraph: Feeding elements or concepts of general interest, not specially adapted for feeding two or more kinds of ammunition or from two sides, are classified in groups F41A9/01 - F41A9/29.

title-part.text: Loading arrangements, i.e. for bringing the ammunition into the firing position
the breech-block itself being the rammer
pushing unbelted ammunition from a box magazine on the gun frame into the cartridge chamber
the cartridge chamber or the barrel as a whole being tiltable
between a loading and a firing position
the cartridge chamber being formed by two complementary elements, movable one relative to the other for loading
using forwardly-sliding barrels or barrel parts for loading

Arrangements for changing from automatic or magazine-loading to hand-loading

guiding means, mounted on, or near, the cartridge chamber

title-part.text: having means for depressing the cartridge follower, or for locking it in a depressed position

title-part.text: Injecting fluids into barrels or cartridge chambers

Systems for cooling the outer surface of the barrel
Cartridge extractors, i.e. devices for pulling cartridges or cartridge cases at least partially out of the cartridge chamber
Cartridge ejectors, i.e. devices for throwing the extracted cartridges or cartridge cases free of the gun

trigger-operated, i.e. the movement of the trigger bringing a hammer safety into inoperative position during firing
